content:
re : 'recent' mode That means: In POP recent mode, Gmail will present all messages from All Mail (Spam and Trash are excluded) from the last 30 days.

So perhaps the recent mode would not be the best setting to download older emails. I'm assuming all those emails are only in the gmail 'Inbox'.


In Thunderbird pop account, Either : create some new folders. eg: Family, Friends, Online Orders, Bills etc and move emails from Inbox into those folders, so the single text file that is receiving those emails does not get too big. The single mbox file must be getting quite large. This means it could be very difficult to compact an enormous file or open it to rescue emails. And it's more risky putting all your eggs in one basket!!

OR access pop 'Account Settings' > 'Copies & Folders'

  • Select 'Keep message archives in:'
  • Select 'Archives folder on' and choose 'pop account name/email address'
  • click on 'Archive Options' button and set to use 'yearly archived folders' and click on 'OK'
  • Then select batches of emails and click on 'Archive'

When emails are all in Archives or other folders,....

  • Right click on Inbox and select 'compact' to remove all traces of moved emails.

Now you should have a clean fresh Inbox ready to receive emails.

Now try 'Get Messages' to see if this will force a download.

If still no joy, logon to gmail webmail account and move all the emails you have already downloaded into another suitably named folder.

content: The message is due to your IP or domain name being on a blacklist or appearing otherwise suspicious as spam. It could be a variety of issues, but it is not caused by your email client. One possibility is incorrect SPF and DKIM settings by your email provider. Did you post the complete error message? I ask that because I usually see additional text following the AUP# Did you make any software changes, such as addition of an antivirus product that forces an ad into the sig?
creator: davidsk

content:
re : error message "The operation failed because another operation is using the folder. Please wait for that operation to finish and then try again."

If this is an imap mail account then there is background communication with the server. If email was fully downloaded then the mbox file will be opened and updated. The index file will also be opened and updated. This will be performed on the Inbox and the Trash files. Data is also communicated over network to update the server.

Many people use an Anti-Virus product and it is likely it may be scanning either an opened file or email. This is usually the most culprit, so the advise is to make the Thunderbird profile folder exempt from scanning.

It is also possible the delete/move email action triggered an auto compact on Inbox file to occur.

content:
The add-on can be downloaded here: https://freeshell.de//~kaosmos/index-en.html#eac

Not sure what the last TB version is that will be compatible, perhaps 52 or 60. All releases are available here:

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/

Recommend you install old versions in separate directories and run on separate profiles. As to usage: copy a message folder (mbox file) to Mail/Local Folders in the separate profile, with TB closed, restart TB, run the crawler on the folder and save to an address book, export the address book to LDIF, import to current version of TB. Clumsy at first, but quick and easy afterwards.

content:
christ1 said
Depending on your email provider, the server may delete messages in the Trash folder after a certain time.

I checked with my host and they do not delete IMAP email files (trash or otherwise). It's a mystery.

It's hard to know which messages will be needed 6 months or 2 years from now, but using the "Archive" feature is a good idea. Thanks.
creator: jl11

content:
Depending on your email provider, the server may delete messages in the Trash folder after a certain time. With IMAP Thunderbird can only see what exists on the server. Check with your email provider.

Having said that, it sounds like a silly idea to me to use Trash as an archive folder. Thunderbird does have a built-in archiving feature. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages

Wrt the lost messages, I'd backup stuff I don't want to lose. You could easily restore messages from a backup, assuming you did take the effort creating one in the first place.
